Available online 10 January 2025 Review Electrochemical CO2RR to C2+ products: A vision of dynamic surfaces of Cu-based catalysts Jinxin Wang Jiaqi Zhang * Chen Chen * Engineering Research Center of Advanced Rare Earth Materials, Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Engineering Research Center of Advanced Rare Earth Materials Department of Chemistry Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Engineering Research Center of Advanced Rare Earth Materials, Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China * Corresponding author. ABSTRACT Electrochemical reduction of CO2 (CO2RR) to form high-energy-density and high-value-added multicarbon products has attracted much attention. Selective reduction of CO2 to C2+ products face the problems of low reaction rate, complex mechanism and low selectivity. Currently, except for a few examples, copper-based catalysts are the only option capable of achieving efficient generation of C2+ products. However, the continuous dynamic reconstruction of the catalyst causes great difficulty in understanding the structure-performance relationship of CO2RR. In this review, we first discuss the mechanism of C2+ product generation. The structural factors promoting C2+ product generation are outlined, and the dynamic evolution of these structural factors is discussed. Furthermore, the effects of electrolyte and electrolysis conditions are reviewed in a vision of dynamic surface. Finally, further exploration of the reconstruction mechanism of Cu-based catalysts and the application of emerging robotic AI chemists are discussed. Graphical Abstract In CO2RR, Cu-based catalysts undergo dynamic reconstruction, impacting their structure and activity. This review provides a dynamic perspective to re-examine catalytic processes, discussing evolution mechanisms, in situ techniques, and electrolytes’ roles. Keywords Electrocatalysis CO2RR Cu-based catalyst Reconstruction Multicarbon product Structural evolution 1 Introduction The continued massive consumption of fossil fuels in modern societies has led to a range of environmental issues, including excessive CO2 emissions, which have resulted in climate change, environmental deterioration and energy crises. In this regard, electrochemical CO2 reduction can convert intermittent electricity into chemical fuels and other value-added products to partially meet the needs of modern society, which not only opens a new path for clean energy utilization, but also holds the potential to reduce the carbon footprint and close the carbon cycle [1–3]. In CO2RR, catalysts play a central role by activating inert CO2 molecules, determining reaction pathways, and improving the activity and selectivity of CO2 conversion. Among the various catalysts, metals are the most extensively studied heterogeneous CO2RR electrocatalysts, and can be classified into three categories based on the main products. Containing Bi, Sn, In, Pb, and Cd (formate as the main product), Au, Ag, and Zn (CO as the main product), and Cu (the only monometallic metal capable of generating multicarbon products with appreciable efficiency). Among these, the development and application of Cu-based catalysts have garnered significant attention due to the higher energy density and added value of the multicarbon products. However, the reaction network for generating multicarbon products is extremely complex, involving multi-step electron/proton transfer reactions and interactions among various intermediates. Moreover, it has been demonstrated that the structure of Cu-based catalysts undergoes dynamic reconstruction under operating conditions, which significantly affects their catalytic performance [4–7]. The reconstruction process is influenced by many factors (electrolyte, electrolysis mode, catalyst structure and microenvironment, etc.). These factors constrain stability and selectivity, complicating the development of structure-activity relationships. Due to dynamic evolution, the characterization of the initial catalyst based on ex situ techniques may not accurately reflect the actual catalytic sites and structure-activity relationships of CO2RR catalysts. Recent advancements in in-situ/operando characterization techniques now enable real-time monitoring of the dynamic evolution and intermediates [8–12]. Combined with density functional theory (DFT) calculations, in-situ/operando studies can help give a picture of how catalytic sites reconstruct during electrolysis and how they influence catalytic performance as well as reaction pathways. In this review, we begin with the discussion of the mechanism of C2+ product (ethylene, ethanol, acetate and propanol, etc.) generation. The structural factors promoting the generation of C2+ products (crystal surfaces, low coordination sites and oxidation states) are reviewed, and the dynamic evolution of these structural factors is discussed. Subsequently, from a perspective of dynamic surfaces, the effects of acid cation effect and pulsed electrochemical method on the catalytic performance are discussed. Finally, we look ahead to the further exploration of reconstruction mechanisms and the application of robotic AI chemists to study CO2RR (Fig. 1 ) 2 Insights into mechanisms of forming C2+ products To enhance the efficiency of catalysts to meet industrial demands, it is essential to investigate the molecular-level pathways that lead to the generation of C2+ products. The production of C2+ products through carbon dioxide reduction reactions (CO2RR) often encounters significant competition from the formation of C1 products and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). More precisely, the preference for producing C2+ over C1 and H2 is critically influenced by factors such as the coverage and binding strength of various intermediates, including *CO, *COOH, *CHO, and *H, on the catalyst surface. Additionally, the coupling energy barriers between these intermediates is crucial in determining the overall reaction pathway. In recent years, numerous experimental data and theoretical studies have contributed to advancing our understanding of these mechanisms. These findings have improved our understanding of this complex reaction. Nevertheless, it is important to acknowledge that despite these advances, a substantial degree of controversy and uncertainty persists in the field. 2.1 C2 pathways One of the most exciting observations in CO2RR is the coupling of two *C1 intermediates to form C–C bonds, ultimately leading to C2 products, of which ethylene, ethanol and acetic acid are the most typical examples. In the entire pathway, CO2 is first activated by a single electron transfer step to form *CO2, and is then reduced to *CO [13]. *CO is the key intermediate for C-C coupling and production of C2+ products [13–16]. In earlier studies, Schouten et al. [17] observed two different ethylene production pathways on single crystal copper surfaces: (1) At high overpotentials, the reaction mainly occurred on Cu(111), involving *CHO, which is a key intermediate in the CH4 pathway. (2) At low overpotential, the reaction mainly occurred on Cu(100) where the CO dimer intermediate was determined to produce C2 products. The two pathways have different pH dependence. Additionally, at more negative potentials, the dimerization of *CO becomes kinetically unfavourable and instead the coupling of *CO to *CHO has a lower activation energy [15]. This dimer intermediate *COCOH on Cu(100) was observed using FTIR at low overpotential, which is consistent with previous research [18,19]. Ethanol is another common C2 product in CO2RR. It is widely acknowledged that ethylene and ethanol share a set of intermediates and undergo the same reaction pathway until the formation of a key selectivity-determining intermediate, which then undergoes two branching processes to either produce ethylene or ethanol. Some studies proposed that *CH2CHO on Cu(100) is the key intermediate [20,21]. On the basis of SERS and DFT, a recent study suggested that Cu sites with distorted coordination environment and deep s-band states stabilize *OCHCH2, opening a route to ethanol [22]. Instead, Cu sites with low coordination numbers enable strong *CO binding and are mainly selective to ethylene via *CO-CO or *CO-COH couplings. Experimental phenomenon indicated acetate is not generated via *CO-CO coupling pathways [23–25]. One of the primary concerns is that CORR often shows higher selectivity for acetate, and that augmenting the partial pressure of CO can further enhance this selectivity. According to the mechanism involving *COCO, increasing the partial pressure of CO should not affect the selectivity of acetate in the C2 products but should instead lead to an overall increase in the yields of all C2 products. Bai et al. [26] proposed a new mechanism for the coupling of *CO with *COOH, which is formed by the oxidation of *CO by surface Cu-OH species, based on a combination of experiments and DFT calculations. Cai et al. [27] performed an extensive investigation into the influence of CO partial pressure on the selectivity of acetic acid. Their DFT calculations revealed that under higher CO partial pressure, the coupling of *CO with *CO2 on Cu(111) becomes more thermodynamically favourable, leading to the formation of the *COCO2 intermediate. This pathway was validated using sophisticated isotope-labelled co-reduction experiments and 1H NMR quantitative studies, in which 13CO2/CO was applied as feedstock. In addition to the aforementioned pathways, several other potential asymmetric C-C coupling pathways have been considered. Several theoretical studies demonstrated that the coupling of *CH x with *CO is thermodynamically and kinetically feasible at specific Cu sites [28,29]. Chen et al. [30] demonstrated the feasibility of coupling *CH3 with *CO on the Cu surface to form C2+ products through co-electrolysis experiments using 13CH3I and 12CO on an electropolished Cu foil. It is important to note that in the same reaction system, different reaction paths may coexist, leading to the formation of diverse products, particularly at high overpotentials. The primary reaction pathways for the C2 products described above are illustrated in Fig. 2 . 2.2 C3 pathways The formation of C3 products is constrained by low selectivity and catalytic activity. Only a limited number of examples of propanol formation have been reported, with all cases exhibiting Faraday efficiencies below 25% [31–36]. It is currently accepted that the formation of C3 products can be reasonably attributed to the formation of C1 intermediates with C2 intermediates relatively stable bound to the catalyst surface. In recent studies, the coupling of two *CO intermediates to *OCCO was hypothesised to be a key step in the formation of propanol on bicontinuous Cu2O/Cu catalysts using in situ ATR-SEIRS which directly detected *OCCO dimers [36,37]. Apart from the self-coupling among *CO intermediates, several studies observed another coupling mechanism between CO and acetaldehyde [38,39]. *CO attacks the *CH3CO derived from acetaldehyde and then a C3 intermediate *CH3COCO is formed. Chang et al. [38] demonstrated that only a minor proportion of the propanol was produced via this pathway when CORR was conducted in an electrolyte containing acetaldehyde, with the majority being generated through self-coupling between *CO intermediates. Nevertheless, the pathway of C3 products is still subject to many controversies and gaps, and some studies have proposed other possible C2 intermediates [33,40]. 3 Structural factors facilitating C2+ production The C1-C1 or C1-C2 coupling is a crucial step in the synthesis of C2+ products. It is therefore essential to systematically optimize the surface of Cu-based catalysts to regulate the adsorption strength and coverage of intermediates and thereby enhancing these coupling processes. This section will present a summary of the surface structural influences that promote the generation of C2+ products. These include crystalline facets, low-coordinated Cu sites, and the oxidation state of Cu. Notably, these structural factors evolve under practical working conditions and significantly affect the catalytic performance. Therefore, the dynamic reconstruction of Cu surfaces must be considered in the design of catalysts. 3.1 Crystalline facets The adsorption energies and coupling energy barriers of intermediates such as *CO, *COOH, *CHO and *H on different crystal surfaces display significant variations, which in turn contribute to the variations in catalytic performance and selectivity (Fig. 3(a) ). It has been demonstrated that the coverage of *CO and the interaction between *CO and *H represent the pivotal factors in the competition between the CH4 and C2H4 pathways (Fig. 3(d)) [41,42]. In general, the adsorption strengths of *CO and *H on the Cu(111) surface are favoured to CH4 production [43]. In contrast, the Cu(100) surface exhibits a higher tendency for the adsorption of *CO. DFT calculations indicate that among all the low-index crystalline surfaces, Cu(100) exhibits the lowest energy barrier for the dimerization of *CO, which is conducive to the formation of C2 products (Fig. 3(b)) [42]. Gregorio et al. [43] compared the catalytic performance of different Cu NCs with a spherical morphology, Cu(100), and Cu(111) facets in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH. A higher selectivity towards ethylene was recorded over Cu(100) catalysts (Fig. 3(a)). Based on this, selective exposure of crystalline facets represents a promising strategy for improving the selectivity of C2 products [44–46]. Jiang et al. [45] increased the exposure of Cu(100) using metal ion battery cycling method, resulting in a sixfold increase in the C2/C1 ratio of the products (Fig. 3(c)) Furthermore, high-index crystalline surfaces can enhance the selectivity of C2+ products even further [47–50]. This argument has been demonstrated by Hori et al. [47,51,52] over a series of Cu catalysts with different single-crystal facets, such as Cu(650), Cu(911), Cu(711). It is noteworthy that the interaction between different crystalline facets of the catalysts may lead to a synergistic effect [53]. Gao et al. [54] prepared three kinds of Cu NPs with different crystal facets. A better selectivity to ethylene was recorded over t-Cu2O NPs, which exposed both (100) and (111) facets (Fig. 3(e)). In situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS), DFT calculations and in situ Raman spectroscopy were employed by Zhong et al. [55] to elucidate the enhancement of C2+ product selectivity by stepped Cu(110) and Cu(100) sites in Cu(OH)2-D/Cu foils. The (110) facet was observed to promote CO adsorption, while the (100) facet was found to facilitate C-C coupling to C2+ products. 3.2 Low-coordinated Cu sites Low-coordinated Cu sites are another structural factor that facilitates C2+ production. Actually, the coordination number may be the underlying cause of the above-mentioned facet-dependence. Different facets have different coordination numbers and different amounts of low-coordinated Cu sites, such as edges, steps, and kinks, and hence they show different selectivities and activities in CO2RR [56]. Among them, Cu sites in the high-index facets or in the boundaries between different facets have lower coordinated numbers and hence demonstrating enhanced catalytic activity towards C2+ products. Stepped sites are one of the typical morphologies of low-coordination Cu [57]. In situ ATR-SEIRAS, DFT calculations and in situ Raman spectroscopy demonstrated that stepped Cu(110) and Cu(100) sites in Cu(OH)2-D/Cu lower the C-C coupling energy barrier [55]. In addition to the stepped sites, another typical morphology of low-coordination Cu is adparticle (Fig. 4(a) ). Theoretical calculations have demonstrated that Cu adparticles with an abundance of low-coordinated Cu sites exhibit enhanced *CO binding strength, facilitate C-C coupling, and stabilize the *COCO dimer [58]. The utilisation of Cu adparticles has emerged as an effective approach for the design of Cu-based catalysts (Fig. 4(b)) [46]. In recent studies, pulsed electrolysis has been demonstrated to be an effective method for the manipulation of coordination numbers of Cu sites (Fig. 4(e)). Cu catalysts with varying coordination numbers were synthesised via cyclic voltammetry, constant potential electrolysis and pulsed electrolysis for the reduction of CuO precursors, with the coordination numbers examined by extended x-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) (Fig. 4(f)) [59]. The results indicated that Cu catalysts after four cycles of pulse electrolysis had excessively low coordination numbers, resulting in the production of CH4 instead of C2+ products. Conversely, Cu catalysts with intermediate coordination numbers demonstrated enhanced catalytic performance for ethylene and ethanol. In addition to modulating the surface structure, the morphology and size of the catalyst also affect the coordination number and abundance of low-coordinated Cu sites [61,62]. Specific morphologies can increase specific surface area and enhance the exposure of unsaturated Cu atoms, leading to the formation of more low-coordinated sites. As an example, copper foil surfaces treated with anodic halogenation in solutions of KCl, KBr, or KI, followed by electroreduction processes formed a high density of unsaturated Cu, which results in the selective conversion of CO2 to C2+ products with a FE of 72% [63]. A series of Cu NCs with different sizes were synthesised by Loiudice et al. [60]. It was observed that the proportion of low-coordinated edge sites increases with the reduction in the size of the nanocube (Fig. 4(d)). The selectivity of the C2+ product exhibited a gradual increase as the size of the NC was reduced to 44 nm. However, further size reduction to 24 nm led to a significant increase in competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), which in turn decreased C2 + product selectivity (Fig. 4(c)). Reske et al. [64] proposed that the binding of *CO and *H is too strong when there are a considerable abundance of Cu sites with CN < 8. This significantly reduces the mobility of the intermediates containing carbon, thereby limiting the subsequent hydrogenation of *CO to form hydrocarbons. This finding is consistent with previous studies indicating that Cu sites with medium coordination numbers are more effective. 3.3 Adjustment of oxidation state The CO2RR catalytic performance of Cu catalysts has been shown to depend on their oxidation state, as evidenced by numerous studies [23,65,66]. Chou et al. [66] investigated this phenomenon using a combination of SEIRS, in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), and DFT calculations. Their findings indicated that CO tends to be in a bridge-adsorbed state on the surface of Cu(0) and in an atop-adsorbed state on the surface of Cu(I). The CV-treated Cu electrodes exhibited the coexistence of Cu(0) and Cu(I), with substantial coverage of both atop-adsorbed and bridge-adsorbed *CO, thereby leading to enhanced C2 selectivity (Fig. 5(a) ). Other studies highlighted the distinctive catalytic performance of the Cu(I)/Cu(0) interface from another perspective [65,67,68]. Here, Cu(0) promotes CO2 activation, while Cu(I) facilitates *CO adsorption and subsequent C-C coupling processes. Performance-time-de- pendent experiments conducted by Lee et al. [69] demonstrated that the Cu(I)/Cu(0) ratio in Cu2O decreased with increasing reaction time, accompanied by a uniform decrease in C2+ product selectivity (Fig. 5(c)). In contrast, Cu(II) is generally regarded as lacking catalytic activity for C2+ products. Tan et al. [70] have achieved the stabilization of Cu(II) by constructing atomic-scale Cu-O-Si interfaces with excellent catalytic performance for CH4. Accordingly, the impact of Cu(II) will not be discussed in this review. In conclusion, these studies have demonstrated that the preservation of Cu(I) species and a high density of Cu(I)/Cu(0) interfaces have a positive influence on the selectively generation of C2 products. The interaction between Cu and other coordination groups enhances the preservation of Cu(I) and increase the ratio of Cu(I)/Cu(0) in CO2RR, thereby optimizing the catalyst stability and the selectivity of C2+ products. In accordance with this strategy, researchers have developed numerous Cu-based precatalysts for obtaining oxidation state-adjustable surface structures through electrochemical reduction reconstruction, thereby achieving the highly selective generation of various CO2 reduction products. As an illustration, Yuan et al. [65] employed CuO/CuSiO3 as a precatalyst and observed that Cu(II) in the CuO crystalline phase was rapidly reduced to Cu(0), whereas the CuSiO3 phase retains a substantial number of Cu(I) species in the CO2RR conditions, the formation of a distinctive Cu(I)/Cu(0) interface occurs, which reaches a Faraday efficiency of 51.8% at –1.1 V RHE for up to 6 h. Furthermore, compounds such as CuI and Cu3N have also demonstrated effective preservation of Cu(I) species (Fig. 5(d)) [72,73]. Molecular doping is another strategy to stabilize Cu(I) species under cathodic potentials. Wu et al. [71] modified the surface of bimetallic silver-copper catalyst with aromatic heterocycles such as thiadiazole and triazole derivatives, which helped maintain the oxidation state of the catalyst and increased the selectivity of C2+ products (Fig. 5(b)). 4 Observation of reconstruction process using in-situ/operando techniques Despite decades of research on Cu-based catalysts in the field of CO2RR, several points of contention remain. For instance, issues such as the relatively poor reproducibility of performance testing in practice, the surface sensitivity of Cu-based materials, the impact of trace impurities in the solution, the significant cation effects of alkali metals, and the substantial role of microenvironmental control are still under debate. In CO2RR, dynamic structural reconstruction is a common phenomenon observed in Cu-based catalysts. Establishing dynamic structure-activity relationships is one of the critical directions for future development in this field. Considering these contentious issues from a dynamic perspective may provide new insights and guidance for advancing this area of research. To study the dynamic surface, in-situ/operando techniques are necessary. Dynamic structural reconstruction causes changes in key structural factors, such as crystalline facets, low-coordinated Cu sites, and oxidation state. Therefore, the actual catalytic sites may differ significantly from the structures characterized using ex-situ techniques (Fig. 6(e) ), When the reaction potential is removed, the material may rapidly revert to a back state [74]. This suggests that ex situ characterisation may give misleading information and cannot precisely reflect the real situation during CO2RR. Dynamic reconstruction affects the intermediate adsorption energy, coverage, charge transfer and microenvironment, and hence alter the catalytic reaction pathway, influencing the catalytic performance. Usually, these dynamic reconstructions are detrimental and can lead to a decrease in the selectivity of the target product and destabilize the catalyst. Even today's state-of-the-art Cu-based catalysts are far from being stable enough to meet industrial requirements, with a maximum lifetime of only a few hundred hours. However, this dynamic reconstruction can also be beneficial. Rational designs of pre-catalysts can induce the subsequent reconstruction processes to achieve the desired tuneable catalytic performance. In addition, the reconstruction process may generate new catalytic sites. Distorted copper sites form during the reconstruction process and can effectively produce ethanol by stabilizing the *OCHCH2 intermediate [22]. Therefore, in order to establish more reliable structure-effect relationships, we need to gain a deeper understanding of the dynamic surfaces of Cu catalysts and to identify the real catalytic sites, which rely on observations using in situ/operando techniques. In this section, on the basis of advanced in situ/operando characterisations, we systematically discuss the dynamic evolution of the key structural factors (morphology, crystalline facets, oxidation state, and coordination environment). It should be clarified that the dynamic changes of the different structural factors occur simultaneously. However, for ease of understanding and discussion, these factors are highlighted separately. 4.1 Morphology evolution Overall, the morphology of Cu electrocatalysts evolves in various forms, and the evolution results including deformation, corrosion, fragmentation, agglomeration, and Ostwald maturation [9,75–77]. The behavior of this morphological evolution is highly complex, especially when considering factors such as CO2 adsorption, electrolyte composition, and applied voltage. Effective techniques for characterizing morphology evolution include electrochemical atomic force microscopy (EC-AFM), electrochemical scanning tunnelling microscopy (EC-STM), and grazing incidence X-ray diffraction (GI-XRD). The entire process of morphology evolution is primarily governed by two mechanisms: the dissolution-deposition mechanism occurring on the surface of individual nanoparticles, and the fragmentation-agglomeration mechanism between nanoparticles. Potential-dependent reconstruction of the surface morphology of the Cu(100) model was tracked using operando electrochemical AFM [78]. In the OCP state, when exposed to 0.1 mol L–1 KHCO3 electrolyte, the originally smooth, terraced field-like structure was quickly covered by spherical particles or sheet-like crystals formed due to oxide deposition (Fig. 6(a)). When the applied potential was varied from 0 to –0.5 V RHE and then to –1 V RHE, the deposited copper oxides were reduced and reconstructed to form mound-like surfaces with primitive square lattices with different periods. This study not only investigated the surface structure that evolved from Cu(100) at varying potentials, but also discovered that the catalyst immersed in the electrolyte undergoes structural evolution even in the absence of a cathodic potential, which was a consequence of dissolved oxygen molecules. The dissolution-deposition process may change the exposed facets, and hence significantly influences the catalytic performance. Kim et al. [62] observed that polycrystalline Cu electrodes underwent a reconstruction process under negative potentials, initially to Cu(111) and then to Cu(100) using operando EC-STM. Additionally, GI-XRD demonstrated the transformation process of polycrystalline Cu into Cu(100) under the catalytic conditions of CO2RR [63]. Theoretical studies indicate that the coverage of *H and *CO jointly influences the reconstruction of specific crystalline surfaces, which elucidates the self-selectivity of the Cu-based catalyst obtained through electrodeposition process [7,64]. The reconstruction of facets led to new catalytic sites, which differed from the structure before electrolysis. Using operando EC-STM and DEMS, a study revealed that the Cu(polycrystalline)-Cu(100) surface undergoes reconstruction to form Cu(S)-[3(100)×(111)] stepped sites during CV tests in 0.1 mol L–1 KOH, which facilitated the formation of ethanol [59]. Catalysts with nanocubic structures (CuNCs) have excellent catalytic performance and selectivity for C2+ products [80]. The sensitivity of their performance to the catalytic environment, such as surface structure, cathodic potential and electrolyte, has received much attention. The dynamic morphological evolutions of Cu NCs loaded on carbon supports under potential control were investigated using electrochemical atomic force microscopy (AFM) (Fig. 6(b)) [4]. The initial Cu NCs were deformed even when exposed to air without applied cathodic bias. Thermodynamically, corners and edges with high curvature and higher surface energy degrade faster than flat surfaces. CO2RR electrolysis at –1.1 V RHE for 1 min results in further surface roughening, smoothing of sharp corners or edges, and reduction of edge length by about 10%. And the Faraday efficiency (especially C2H4 selectivity) of CO2RR gradually decreased with the structural transformation after electrolysis at –1.1 V RHE for 3 h. Huang et al. [7] used in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to observe the structural evolution of Cu NCs on the working electrode. Based on the in-situ observation, a reconstruction mechanism involving two stages was proposed (Fig. 6(d)). In the first stage, H* or CO* intermediates adsorbed on the Cu surface induce nanoclustering, which roughens the Cu NCs while forming small nanofragments. In the second stage, nanoclustering continues and is accompanied by agglomeration. In addition, clearer structure-property relationships were revealed by in situ high-resolution scanning electrochemical cell microscopy (SECM) and electron backscattering diffraction (EBSD), which directly showed that the excellent catalytic performance of CO2 is associated with a large number of undercoordinated sites in nanograins where high geometrically necessary dislocations are present (Fig. 6(c)) [79,81]. Recently, Yang et al. [74] developed a time-resolved four-dimensional electrochemical liquid-cell scanning transmission electron microscopy (4D-STEM) operando technique and demonstrated that pre-catalyst Cu NPs deform and distort under CO2RR conditions and further aggregate to form abundant Cu-metallic nanograins (Fig. 6(e)). Further, in combination with operando XAS, the researchers illustrated the correlation between the abundance of nanograins and abundant low-coordinated Cu sites, which promotes C-C coupling and subsequent generation of C2+ products. Moreover, as the size of the pre-catalyst Cu NPs decreases, more nanograins are formed by reconstruction. The results show that the C2+ product selectivity exhibited by the 7 nm Cu NPs ensemble is 6 times higher than that of 18 nm Cu NPs (Fig. 6(f)). It is noteworthy that under ex situ conditions, the Cu catalysts after electrolysis is rapidly transformed into Cu nanocubes in the presence of moist air, with a structure very different from that under practical working conditions. This phenomenon again emphasizes the need of using in-situ or operando techniques to probe the dynamic reconstruction of the catalyst. 4.2 Evolution in oxidation state The oxidation state of Cu-based catalysts continuously evolved under practical working conditions. Pourbaix diagram for Cu provide a thermodynamic basis for predicting the most stable form of Cu in aqueous solution at a given pH and potential. As illustrated in the Pourbaix diagram (Fig. 7(d) ), the stable equilibrium phase under CO2RR conditions is Cu(0). However, this suggestion is contradicted by numerous experimental evidence. For instance, oxide-derived Cu catalysts were observed to preserve significant quantities of Cu(I) species under CO2RR conditions. This indicates that, in addition to thermodynamic factors, numerous kinetic and environmental factors in real conditions exert a considerable influence on the oxidation state of Cu. The earliest observation of the preservation of Cu(I) species in Cu2O at the reduction potential was made by Lee et al. [69]. According to the chemical properties of Cu, Cu is easily oxidized when exposed to air in the electrolyte under OCP. On the other hand, under the operating conditions with applied cathodic potential, the oxide species will be reduced to a lower valence state to some extent depending on the potential range. It should be emphasized that even during the short OCP residence time between cathodic electrolysis intervals, the low valence state is rapidly oxidized to the high valence state by the dissolved oxygen in the electrolyte. Therefore, a dynamic reduction-reoxidation process occurs over the Cu-based catalyst during CO2RR. The repeated delocalization-embedding process of lattice oxygen atoms during this cycling process, which leads to a change in the coordination environment, another important factor of the oxidation state, and thus further modulates the catalytic selectivity, as the phenomenon we observed in the structural characterization of OD-Cu. In situ XAS is widely utilized to trace the evolution of oxidation state. In recent years, numerous reports have focused on the relationship between the catalytic performance of CO2RR and the dynamic evolution of the oxidation state. Sargent et al. [23] studied the evolution of the oxidation state of CuO during CO2RR using in situ XAS and found that Cu(II) was rapidly reduced to Cu(I) in less than 5 min, whereas the reduction of Cu(I) to Cu(0) was much slower. Even when maintained at –1.2 V RHE for 1 h, the catalyst still preserved a significant proportion of the Cu(I) species (Fig. 7(a)). At room temperature, oxidizing OH radicals are readily generated in aqueous HCO3 – solutions, and the rapid oxygen exchange between HCO3 – and H2O provides a dynamic oxygen source for the formation of OH radicals (Fig. 7(c)). Using electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), Mu et al. [6] identified highly oxidized hydroxyl (OH) radicals formed in KHCO3 solution at room temperature. By combining in situ Raman spectroscopy, secondary ion mass spectrometry, and isotopic labelling, they confirmed the dynamic reduction/reoxidation behaviour of the OD-Cu surface and showed that the rapid oxygen exchange between HCO3 – and H2O provides an oxygen source for the formation of OH radicals (Figs. 7(b), (e)–(g)). In addition, the continuous generation of OH radicals induced spontaneous oxidation of the Cu electrode, producing surface CuO x species. It is noteworthy that this work demonstrates the existence of a dynamic equilibrium between cathodic reduction and OH-induced reoxidation, which ultimately determines the oxidation state and abundance of Cu(I) during CO2RR. The evolution of the oxidation state implies the reorganization of the metal coordination environment and oxygen removal, which may cause changes in the morphology. In fact, some catalysts with rough surfaces enriched in low-coordinated Cu sites are prepared via electrochemical reconstruction during potentiostatic reduction or pulsed electrolysis [5,84,85]. In a recent study, Long et al. [35] recently investigated the reconstruction process of CuO and Cu2O at the reduction potential using molecular dynamics simulations. Due to the more vigorous oxygen removal process, CuO produces more low-coordinated Cu sites and higher surface roughness than Cu2O, which was characterized by in situ XAS as well as electrochemical tests (Fig. 8(b) ). Fang et al. [82] synthesized a series of Cu2O nanocrystals with different polyhedral shapes and found that with the increase of the number of faces of the polyhedral, the more edge sites the Cu2O nanocrystals have, the lower the coordination number of the Cu catalyst obtained after CO2RR, with better ethylene selectivity (Fig. 8(a)). This study suggests that the reconstructed Cu catalyst maintains some of the coordination properties of the pre-catalyst Cu2O, and its coordination number can be adjusted by controlling the morphology of the pre-catalyst. Wang et al. [5] found that homogeneous CuAg oxides underwent a reduction reaction under COR conditions, and the structure evolved into Ag nanoparticles encapsulated in amorphous Cu thin layers. Sang et al. [84] synthesized Cu2P2O7 catalysts, which were electrochemically reduced to the metallic state Cu, the morphology undergoes a remarkable reconstruction from agglomerated grains to highly porous structure with large electrochemically active surface area and abundant defects (Figs. 8(d) and (e)). Additionally, the morphology reconstruction also affects the oxidation state evolution. Yang et al. [83] found that the in situ formation of nanocavities in the Cu catalysts confined the carbon-containing intermediates and increased the local concentration of these intermediates, which resulted in a better ability of the cavities to preserve the Cu(I) (Fig. 8(c)). In conclusion, the oxidation state evolution process of Cu-based catalysts can be divided into two categories: first, the dynamic equilibrium between the oxidation of the catalyst surface in the presence of dissolved oxygen or OH radicals and the reduction by the cathodic current; and second, the drastic reconstruction of Cu oxides as precatalysts, which occurs in the early stage of electrolysis, and the removal of a large number of oxygen atoms that may cause the change of morphology. This process is affected by factors such as the structure of the precatalyst, the electrolyte, and the applied potential, and more seriously, there is an interference between the evolution of the oxidation state and the reconstruction of the morphology, which makes the mechanism extremely complex. 5 A vision of dynamic surfaces: Atomic-level mechanisms and the origin of catalytic activity Recently, with advancements in characterization techniques, the study of electrochemical catalytic processes has reached an atomic-level observation. By employing environmental aberration-corrected atomic-resolution electron microscopy combined with EELS spectroscopy, ultra-high-resolution mass spectrometry, and surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy, we can piece together a more comprehensive understanding of the evolving mechanisms of copper catalysts in the CO2RR through multidimensional information. Consequently, copper-based catalysts can be examined from a new perspective: that of dynamic surfaces. This perspective is founded on our in-depth understanding of the laws governing the dynamic reconstruction processes. There are several key points: (1) What is the mechanism of the reconstruction process? How to understand the reconstruction process at the atomic level? (2) What's the result of the reconstruction? (3) What is the law of changing the catalyst surface structure during the reconstruction process? Which factors (potential, pH, electrolyte and pre-catalyst structure, etc.) can affect this process? Although there are still many gaps and controversies in this area, the efforts of researchers have achieved many exciting results. This section begins with a description of the atomic-level mechanisms of dynamic reconstruction. Then, focusing on electrolytes and electrolytic condition as two illustrative examples, we'll discuss how these factors can be understood with a vision of dynamic surfaces. 5.1 Atomic-level mechanisms of the dynamic reconstruction In order to elucidate the impact of various factors on the dynamic evolution of the surface and their underlying mechanisms, and subsequently to regulate and induce dynamic reconstruction to enhance the stability and the selectivity of C2+ products, it is essential to gain a fundamental understanding of the mechanism of dynamic reconstruction at the atomic level. In this regard, several key points have been identified: (1) the activation of Cu atoms on the surface; (2) the existence state and characteristics of activated Cu detached from the surface; and (3) the deposition process of detached Cu. Recent experimental and theoretical studies suggest that *H and *CO adsorbed on the Cu surface are the key intermediates for dynamic reconstruction, participating in the redox cycle of Cu(I)/Cu(0) [8,86,87]. Amirbeigiarab et al. [8] conducted an investigation into the reconstruction process of Cu(100) electrodes with flat terrace morphology in a CO2-saturated KHCO3 solution using in situ STM, in situ SXRD, and SERS. Cu clusters formed on the surface within the potential range where CO was simultaneously generated. During the reversible formation and dissolution process of Cu cluster, the electrode surface underwent irreversible roughening due to the formation of attached Cu atoms with vacancies (Fig. 9(a) ). In this study, it was postulated that Cu atoms were seized by adsorbed *CO. Recently, Zhang et al. [86] combined a quasi-kinetic Monte Carlo simulation and a potential-dependent grand canonical ensemble representation to track the reconstruction of Cu(100) surface during a simulated cathodic scanning period (Figs. 9(h)–(j)). Their findings suggest a potential mechanism whereby the synergistic role of *H and *CO promotes reconstruction. A chemical bonding analysis indicates that the combined effect of the weakening of the surface Cu–Cu bond by H and the coordination of the strong ligand CO at the top is responsible for the elevation of Cu*CO. In the absence of CO, Cu raised slowly with the increase of *H coverage. Instead, when CO is coordinated to Cu, Cu*CO species raised sharply with the increase of *H (Fig. 9(i)). Molecular dynamics simulations and free energy calculations revealed that the two Cu*COs may dimerize at a slightly higher potential barrier, which could be a potential mechanism for further cluster aggregation and island formation (Fig. 9(j)). The aforementioned studies have indicated that the adsorbed species *H and *CO play a role in activating the surface Cu atoms and driving further reconstruction. In order to determine the oxidation state of the activated Cu species involved in reconstruction, Vavra et al. [89] employed a combination of online MS and UV-vis absorption spectroscopy using 1,10-phenanthroline (dmphen) as ligands to investigate the dissolution-redeposition process in the reconstruction of Cu surfaces (Fig. 9(f)). Dmphen ligands were applied to capture and stabilize transient Cu(I) intermediates, facilitating the formation of photoreactive Cu(dmphen)2 +, which can be detected by UV-vis absorption spectroscopy. The experimental data indicated that the soluble, transient intermediates contained Cu(I) species (Fig. 9(g)). The researchers then hypothesize that [CuCO]+ and [Cu2C2O4]– may serve as possible intermediates, whose reductive redeposition results in the reconstruction and the roughening of Cu surface. Direct observation of the atomic dynamics of electrified solid-liquid interfaces (ESLIs) at negative potentials is very challenging because the interfaces are buried in a liquid electrolyte and techniques for in situ imaging through liquids have limited spatial resolution. In a recent study, Zhang et al. [88] developed an advanced polymer electrochemical liquid cell for TEM to monitor the atomic dynamics of the dynamic reconstruction process of ESLIs during the Cu-catalysed CO2 electroreduction reaction (Figs. 9(b)–(d)). With the change of applied potential, fluctuating liquid-like amorphous structures were observed on the surface of Cu nanowires using TEM, flowing along the Cu surface or interconverting with the crystalline phase Cu and causing surface roughening. EDS and EELS analyses of the frozen amorphous surface phases showed the presence of both Cu(0) and Cu(I) and the identification of the elements C, O, and H, which is consistent with the [CuCO]+ intermediates postulated in previous studies. At the atomic level, the researchers observed that attached atoms, atomic steps, vacancies, and ridges formed at the interface between amorphous Cu and crystalline phase Cu, and these defect sites changed dynamically with the motion of amorphous Cu (Fig. 9(d)). It is noteworthy that Cu atoms can also be removed from the atomic platforms at the interface between crystalline Cu and the electrolyte, but the resulting vacancies are rapidly refilled to obtain smooth atomic platform again. This suggests that the dynamic reconstruction of the Cu surface occurs mainly at the interface between amorphous Cu and crystalline Cu, rather than at the interface between electrolyte and crystalline Cu (Fig. 9(b)). In this study, the formation of a liquid-like amorphous structure and its atomic dynamics involved in the reconstruction of the Cu surface were observed using in situ TEM. It is intriguing to guess whether this *CO-rich amorphous Cu will act as a catalytic phase and participate in the reaction of CO2 electroreduction to form multicarbon products or not. Li et al. [90] developed an electrified operando-freezing methodology to freeze the dynamic surfaces and interfaces under CO2RR conditions for cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM) imaging and EELS detection. Cu clusters and nanoparticles from fragmentation were observed after 10 mins. EELS demonstrated that these freshly formed nanoparticles were also covered by an amorphous Cu(I) layer, of which the thickness was less than 1 nm. This is consistent with the above study. Additionally, it indicated that the amorphous Cu(I) layer not only causes the roughening of Cu surfaces, but is also involved in the fragmentation and agglomeration. Further investigation is required to ascertain the role of this amorphous interface in other reconstruction modes, such as segregation, Ostwald ripening, coalescence, and so forth [91]. 5.2 Understanding the electrolyte effect In addition to the structures of catalysts, CO2RR is also influenced by environmental factors, including electrolyte, pH, and ligand modification. In previous studies on these factors, due to the limitations of theoretical computational resources, Cu catalysts have often been presented as static models. However, as previously stated, dynamic reconstruction of Cu during CO2RR universally occurs and significantly affects catalytic performance and selectivity. These environmental factors affect the water network at the catalyst interface, the local electric field and concentration of each species. It seems reasonable to posit that these alterations will affect the dynamic reconstruction, which in turn will alter the catalytic performance. An examination of the influence of these environmental factors on the dynamic surface may prove an important addition to our understanding of the effects of these factors on catalytic performance. However, only few reports researched the influence of these environmental factors on Cu surface reconstruction and their mechanisms. The cations in the electrolyte have a significant effect on the product selectivity in CO2RR. For the selectivity of C2+ products, the overall trend follows Cs+ > K+ > Na+ > Li+. Several hypotheses have been proposed to understand the underlying mechanisms [11,87,92–94]. It is usually assumed that cations in the electrical double layer alter the surface water network, which in turn affects the adsorption and activation of CO2 and its subsequent hydrogenation process. Using in situ SEIRS, it was found that the CO coverage under reaction conditions was rather lower in KHCO3 than in NaHCO3, suggesting that CO coverage is not a key factor in cation effect (Fig. 10(a) ) [92]. Further DFT calculations showed that CO2 δ– on the surface pulls K+ and Cs+, which are weakly hydrated, closer to the surface, lowering the energy barrier for *CO dimerisation and subsequent hydrogenation (Figs. 10(b) and (c)). Yang et al. [93] suggested that Li+ is more distant from the Cu surface and unlikely to coordinate with *CO + *CO. Consequently, the C-C coupling is stabilised mainly by hydrogen bonding provided by surrounding water molecules, which significantly promotes the hydrogenation of *CO and reduces the selectivity of C2 products. In contrast, the larger cation K+ can coordinate with *CO + *CO, which contributes little to the coupling barrier but creates a hydrophobic microenvironment that inhibits conversion to the C1 pathway and improves the selectivity of C2 products (Fig. 10(g)). Zhang et al. [11] investigated the cation effect of Cu-catalysed CO2RR in acidic electrolytes in combination with ATR-SEIRAS and AIMD. It was found that adsorbed CO2 and other intermediates won't be detected without the addition of alkali-metal cations, and only HER occurred (Fig. 10(d)). Contrary to common perspective, time-resolved IR spectroscopy showed that Li+ enhanced CO2 adsorption more efficiently than the other larger cations (e.g., Na+, K+, and Cs+) but slowed down the kinetics of the hydrogenation of CO2 (Figs. 10(d)–(f)). The researchers suggest that the more flexible water network surrounding the larger cations promotes water reorientation and enhances the contact between hydrogen and CO2, speeding up the hydrogenation kinetics. In a recent study, Liu et al. [10] revealed an alkali cation-induced reconstruction mechanism of Cu catalysts using in situ TEM, XAFS and CV (Fig. 10(h)). It was found that in the absence of alkali cations, the surface evolution of Cu NCs was limited to the reduction of the surface oxide layer. In contrast, in the presence of alkali metal cations, Cu NCs underwent significant morphological changes, and the depth of corrosion increased from Li+ to Cs+ (Fig. 10(i)). Based on the aforementioned principles of cation effects and reliable experimental studies on cation-induced reconstruction, along with a comparison of the key intermediate Cu*CO, we reasonably speculate that the Cu-CO-M+ structure is a primary factor contributing to the phenomenon of cation-induced reconstruction. Simple H+ ions are not sufficient to easily induce surface reconstruction of copper. The presence of cations in the solution can interact with the oxygen end of CO, pulling Cu atoms from the surface due to the solvation effect of water molecules. For Li+, its thicker hydration layer makes it difficult to coordinate with CO. Larger cations, like Cs+, due to their stronger interactions with CO, are more likely to induce surface reconstruction of the catalyst, thereby affecting the reaction pathway. As mentioned above, the surface of Cu catalysts continuously reconstructs, which is induced by *H and *CO intermediates, resulting in a dynamic formation-quenching process of the catalytic sites on the surface (low-coordinated Cu, stepped Cu sites, and Cu0/Cu1 interfaces, etc.). With this perspective of dynamic surfaces, environmental factors such as electrolytes, ligand modifications, pH, etc. can significantly affect the adsorption of *H and *CO, and thus the dynamic surfaces of Cu. Consequently, these factors are likely to change the abundance and dynamic distribution of catalytic sites, leading to different catalytic performance and selectivity. In addition, some molecular additives can also stabilize or induce the reconstruction of Cu-based catalysts, thereby altering the dynamic surfaces [95]. For example, EDTMPA can selectively absorb onto Cu(110), lowering the surface energy of Cu(110), and hence induce the transformation of other facets to (110) [96]. Methanethiol monolayers on Cu surface induced the reconstruction via reductive desorption during CO2RR, thereby increasing surface roughness [97]. A similar phenomenon of reductive desorption was observed for Cu catalysts coated with Zr-based metal-organic layers [98]. In conclusion, molecular additives can influence the reconstruction of Cu-based catalysts through adsorption, reductive desorption, or charge transfer, thereby impacting catalytic performances. 5.3 Perfecting the electrolysis conditions The surface of the Cu catalyst is subject to continuous reconstruction throughout the CO2RR process, resulting in a dynamic structure that is inherently non-equilibrium. Prolonged application of the reduction potential may result in the catalyst deviating increasingly from its initial structure. This not only leads to a loss of the expected catalytic performance or even complete loss of CO2RR catalytic activity, but also presents a challenge in identifying the real catalytic sites during the reaction. In recent years, researchers have made significant advancements in enhancing catalyst stability by designing special electrolysis conditions, including regeneration and pulse electrolysis. These methods facilitate the regeneration of active sites or induce cyclical structural changes within a narrow range, thereby improving its stability and resilience [99–102]. Regeneration represents a typical strategy for renewing catalytic activity. This is achieved by regenerating the catalytic active sites and the reaction microenvironment, thereby extending the lifetime of CO2 electrolysis. The most used regeneration method is to refresh the electrolyte in a long-term test. Furthermore, a distinctive electrolysis mode comprising alternating “on” and “off” operating segments was employed to regenerate the reactivity sites and enhance the CO2RR stability (Fig. 11(a) ) [102]. During the 15 min “off” period, the cathodic potential was removed, the Cu catalyst surface was oxidized by dissolved O2 molecules, and the restoration of the Cu oxide phase was observed using Raman spectroscopy, which led to the regeneration of the catalytic activity of ethylene. The application of the aforementioned “on-off” strategy, comprising two alternating “on” (15 min) and “off” (15 min) operating segments, extended the lifetime of CO2 electroreduction ethylene production to 200 h, with negligible or no degradation in selectivity. The output voltage of pulsed electrolysis varies between a higher and a lower potential, which is promising for the Cu catalyst to be “reset” at higher potentials to counteract the reconstruction in CO2RR. This allows for periodic alteration of the catalyst structure within a narrow range, which notably enhances stability while facilitating the identification of catalytic sites. The application of AFM revealed that the morphological change of Cu NCs after pulse electrolysis was much smaller than that of constant potential electrolysis and the structural change can be influenced by the width of the applied potential window (Fig. 11(g)) [106]. Furthermore, it was demonstrated by operando XAS that pulsed electrolysis has a good reservation ability for Cu(I) species, which can still be observed even when the reaction stops at the reduction potential pulse. Using time-resolved in situ Raman spectroscopy with a time resolution of 0.25 s, the periodic changes of *CO intermediates and the oxidation-reduction cyclic transitions of Cu x O-Cu phases were observed in real time within a single pulse cycle, using polycrystalline copper foils as a model system (Figs. 11(e) and (f)) [105]. Utilizing time-resolved in situ Raman, it was demonstrated that tuning the pulse length could optimize the surface adsorption of species on the Cu-based catalysts, particularly the co-adsorption of *OH and *CO, which significantly affects the adsorption kinetics of CO and enhances the selectivity of ethanol (Figs. 11(d) and (h)) [104]. Kok et al. [103] found that increasing the oxygen flux during pulsed electrolysis further prolonged the catalyst lifetime and reduced the time of the “off” operating segments, which improved the electrolysis efficiency (Figs. 11(b), (c)). This finding is also consistent with previous studies that have indicated that Cu(I) species may promote C2 product selectivity. The optimization of electrolysis conditions has great potential in improving catalyst stability and modulating product selectivity. In the future, it is necessary to further investigate the mechanism of the effect of electrolysis conditions on catalytic performance and to develop new electrolysis conditions, such as applying linearly varying potentials or sinusoidal potentials. 6 Summary and perspectives In summary, we have provided an overview of the dynamic surfaces of copper-based catalysts in the CO2RR. We began with the mechanisms for the formation of C2+ products and the key structural factors of Cu-based catalysts. Next, we highlighted the recent advancements in in situ characterization techniques that enhance our understanding of the reaction mechanisms and dynamic processes involved in CO2RR, summarizing the latest research on morphological changes and the evolution of oxidation states, as well as the corresponding changes in surface species and reaction mechanisms. Subsequently, from the perspective of dynamic surfaces and utilizing cutting-edge technologies, we reinterpreted the atomic-level mechanisms of reconstruction and examined the influence of electrolyte effect and electrolysis conditions from this dynamic vision. With the advancement of various in-situ and operando techniques, researchers have achieved many exciting advances. In our perspective, the future opportunities and challenges for CO2RR are as follows. 6.1 Development of multidimensional in situ observation techniques Despite the plethora of promising findings in recent years, the field of dynamic reconstructions of Cu still exhibits significant gaps in knowledge. In general, in addition to surface roughening, catalysts may undergo several reconstruction processes, including fragmentation, aggregation, Ostwald ripening, remodelling, and oxidation-reduction. These processes encompass not only the dissolution-deposition mechanism on the surface of individual nanoparticles, the atomic-level mechanism of which has recently been elucidated, but also the aggregation mechanism between nanoparticles. In order to gain a deeper understanding of these processes and to be able to control them, it is essential to gain further insight into their dynamics, in particular at the atomic level. This may require simultaneous observations at both the micro and nano scales, while utilizing advanced spectroscopic techniques to identify intermediate information, aimed at recognizing the active complexes or phases that dominate these reconstruction processes and investigating the conditions and environments under which these active complexes or phases form. Moreover, due to the surface sensitivity of copper-based materials, it is crucial to ensure that in situ observation techniques do not interfere with the normal progression of the reactions. For example, when using high-resolution liquid-phase TEM, high-energy electron beams can lead to thermal damage and radiation decomposition of the materials, particularly at atomic-level resolutions, which may cause the detected materials to deviate from real operational conditions. Therefore, developing low-beam-current, high-sensitivity sensors, employing algorithms for image enhancement, and utilizing cryo-electron microscopy to study reaction processes through time slicing can provide more information while reducing electron beam damage. Spectroelectrochemistry is also a powerful tool in studying the dynamics of CO2RR; however, it is important to note that as spectral sensitivity improves, an increasing number of “false” intermediates may interfere with the testing process. Some adsorbed species, despite their presence, may be inert and not genuinely participate in the reaction, serving merely as bystanders. Additionally, spectroscopy tends to detect strongly adsorbed species, whereas some key species may be weakly adsorbed or have short lifetimes. This necessitates that researchers advance qualitative analysis to a quantitative level while obtaining deeper insights through methods such as gas feed switching. In the future, studies using in situ high-resolution mass spectrometry may also prove to be significant. 6.2 Researching CO2RR with robotic AI chemists Robotic AI chemists consist of a superbrain built on neural networks, large language models, and high-quality DFT simulation data, along with mechanical and mobile structures designed for hands-on experimentation. In simulating calculations for reconstruction or dynamic surfaces, the effects of solvation and various ions are often overlooked due to computational resource limitations. Large-scale surface structures require substantial computational resources, which can further distance models from actual conditions. As emphasized in Section 5, electrolytes significantly impact the dynamic reconstruction of copper-based catalysts, potentially altering catalytic sites. This makes models that ignore solvation and ionic effects deviate from reality. Monte Carlo simulations serve as a powerful algorithmic tool, capable of coarse-graining atoms within the system and achieving dynamical simulations over extended timescales. Zhang et al. [86] utilized quasi-dynamic Monte Carlo simulations to reveal the evolutionary pathways of the system in coverage space during the CO2RR process on copper surfaces, exploring the recombination of surface chemical spaces with mixed adsorbates Cu*CO and Cu*H and their non-equilibrium evolution. Machine learning has a unique advantage in exploring the collective impacts of multiple variables, enabling a more accurate reflection of the relationships between various influences and catalytic performance. Several studies have demonstrated the advantages of machine learning in probing the dynamic behaviour of Cu catalysts. To realise industrial applications of CO2RR, high selectivity and long-term stability are key parameters. And these parameters are influenced various factors (electrolyte, device, electrolysis method, etc.), not only the catalyst. The use of polymer membrane electrode assemblies is expected to increase the current density and meet industrial demands, with CO2 and H2O producing multicarbon products such as ethylene, ethanol, acetic acid and n-propanol at the cathode. The goal is to improve reaction rates, single product selectivity, stability and energy efficiency performance. However, the reaction occurs at the gas-liquid-solid three-phase interface and involves many factors such as catalyst structure, microenvironment, electrolyte and various intermediates. More seriously, all these factors are under dynamic change, which poses a challenge to understand and construct more exact structure-effect relationships. For example, the Cu-based catalyst structure undergoes dynamic changes in features such as morphology and oxidation state under actual working conditions, and the microenvironment as well as the electrolyte composition also change during the CO2RR process. Moreover, these factors do not occur independently but interact with each other, which greatly increases the complexity of the reaction system. This not only makes it often difficult for theoretical models to exactly reflect the real situation, but also impairs the repeatability of experiments. In the current research context, decoupling these complex factors is quite challenging. To accelerate material development through large-scale data mining and material screening, abstracting all factors into a black box and then progressively dissecting the influencing factors using machine learning is an effective approach [107–110]. However, the effectiveness of machine learning heavily depends on the quality of the database, which is determined by the simplification and standardization of various experimental testing steps. AI chemists, who standardize and systematically complete standard tests, using comparison samples with similar structures, will generate high-quality datasets [111,112]. This process will become a powerful tool for accelerated material screening and optimization in the field of CO2RR. In summary, there is great room for progress in the study of the dynamic behaviors and evolutionary processes of copper-based materials in the understanding CO2RR. This advancement requires the development of multidimensional advanced characterization techniques, quantitative spectroscopic analyses, and the retrospective development of high-quality material datasets. We need to gain a deeper understanding of electrochemical reaction processes from a dynamic vision to guide the rational design of stable, controllable, and efficient CO2RR catalysts for the production of C2+ products in the future. Jiaqi Zhang (Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University) received his B.S. degree from China University of Petroleum (East China) in 2020 and is currently pursuing his Ph.D. at Tsinghua University. His research focuses on nanomaterials for electrocatalysis and electrochemical synthesis. Chen Chen (Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University) received his B.S. degree from the Department of Chemistry, Beijing Institute of Technology in 2006, and his Ph.D. degree from the Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University in 2011. After postdoctoral work at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, he joined the Department of Chemistry at Tsinghua University as an Associate Professor in 2015, and was promoted to Professor with tenure in 2021. His name is in the lists of Highly Cited Researchers 2021–2023 from Clarivate. His research interests are focused on nanomaterials for catalysis and sustainable energy.

coredata.dc:description: ABSTRACT Electrochemical reduction of CO2 (CO2RR) to form high-energy-density and high-value-added multicarbon products has attracted much attention. Selective reduction of CO2 to C2+ products face the problems of low reaction rate, complex mechanism and low selectivity. Currently, except for a few examples, copper-based catalysts are the only option capable of achieving efficient generation of C2+ products. However, the continuous dynamic reconstruction of the catalyst causes great difficulty in understanding the structure-performance relationship of CO2RR. In this review, we first discuss the mechanism of C2+ product generation. The structural factors promoting C2+ product generation are outlined, and the dynamic evolution of these structural factors is discussed. Furthermore, the effects of electrolyte and electrolysis conditions are reviewed in a vision of dynamic surface. Finally, further exploration of the reconstruction mechanism of Cu-based catalysts and the application of emerging robotic AI chemists are discussed.
